data.title: selecting text in the debug console adds an "ESLint" to status bar
data.body:
testing #26736:

While testing #26736 I noticed that selecting in the debug console adds an "ESLint" to the right hand side of my status bar.

What is the reason for this? Looks strange.

(I have extension ESLint 1.2.11 installed)

data.title: editor.multicursorModifier: cmd should be the default
data.body:
Testing https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/27480

We should change our default to `editor.multicursorModifier: cmd` to follow what other editors do.

data.title: Playground: Turn off minimaps
data.body:
The playground editors seem to all have minimaps enabled.
As the editors are always very small they don't offer any benefit and also, IMO, don't look so good.

I'd suggest to not show them.

data.title: Welcome page: Use focus border color
data.body:
Testing #27431 

- open the welcome page, press tab
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6461412/26576109/fb2f5462-4527-11e7-8d35-afff49237606.png)

The focus border should use the color `focusBorder` to match other focus borders in the UI.

data.title: TerminalBehaviour - use US-english names
data.body: It should be `TerminalBehavior` not the oxford english variant if `ou`

data.title: Welcome page: Use 'textLink.activeForeground'
data.body:
Testing #27431

When hovering over one of the links, 'textLink.activeForeground' should be used.

data.title: Extension editor: scroll position is not restored.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

Testing: #27350 

- VSCode Version: 1.13 insider
- OS Version: Linux Fedora

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open extension editor
1. scroll the content
1. switch to another editor in the same group
1. switch back to extension editor

Observe: scroll position is not restored

data.title: Improve color names for welcome page
data.body:
Testing #27431

The color names for the welcome page should match the color id naming guidelines:

- `welcomePage.caption` -> `welcomePage.foreground`
The color default should be `foreground` or be derived from `foreground`

- `welcomePage.detail` -> `welcomePage.descriptionForeground`
The color default should be `descriptionForeground` or be derived from `descriptionForeground`

- welcomePage.quickLinkBackground
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6461412/26574791/ffb63ef6-4522-11e7-9674-d35ff4d5928a.png)
Maybe call it a button?  -> `welcomePage.buttonBackground`
- `welcomePage.quickLinkHoverBackground` -> `welcomePage.buttonHoverBackground`

- `walkThrough.embeddedEditorBackground` -> `welcomePagePlaygroundEditor.background`

- `welcomeOverlay.foreground` & `welcomeOverlay.background`
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6461412/26575128/342d8346-4524-11e7-8531-a9d19ae97c7a.png)
I think that these colors are too specific and think we should keep them internal for now. I think it's ok to just use transparency for the background. The foreground should use either welcomePage.captionForeground or welcomePage.detailForeground

data.title: Markdown preview doesn't respond to scrolling with finger
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2 (19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de, 2017-05-10T13:20:36.315Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393

---

Steps to Reproduce:

**Laptop with touch screen required**

1. Open any .md file
2. Click on "Open preview to the side" button.
3. Try touch-scroll the preview area:
    1. *Expected result*: both preview and editor areas follow finger movements and scroll, like it works for wheel-scrolling.
    2. *Actual result*: nothing happens, preview area doesn't scroll at all.
4. Scrolling editor area with finger works the same way as scrolling it with wheel (or touch pad)

data.title: Find widget covers find result when at the first line
data.body:
Testing #27412:

OS: Windows 10

1. Open new empty plain text file
2. Copy paste the following text into it:

> Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.Proin hendrerit orci in dignissim consequat.Integer ultricies nunc eu massa aliquam tristique.Donec nisl ex, imperdiet ut ultricies eget, volutpat eu nisl.Aliquam varius tincidunt sapien, a pretium mi vulputate sit amet.Sed augue sem, feugiat vel dapibus vel, condimentum a augue.Nam fringilla diam vitae turpis pretium ultricies.Nulla ac ornare dui.Curabitur lacinia felis vitae justo rutrum, et sodales risus congue.Integer posuere felis sed ligula sagittis consectetur.Integer condimentum consequat facilisis.

3. Ctrl+F, search for `varius` (or any word that is supposed to be under the find widget).
-> Match is hidden beneath the search widget, although scrolling up reveals it.

I would expect to reveal the match when I hit it, when searching, so that I don't need to scroll back and forth to understand where is the match, if I am a first-time VS Code user.

As a suggestion maybe it is better to do the scrolling the editor up on the user behalf, revealing the search match?

data.title: Entering and leaving directory statements are not processed, resulting in incorrect paths for the problemMatcher
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12
- OS Version: Mac OS 10.12.5 & Ubuntu 16.04
Steps to Reproduce:

1. download e.g. bash source code from GitHub
2. In top source dir mkdir build; cd build; ../configure; make 
If the make is done from within studio code, it can be seen that some paths to warnings are resolved properly, but others, to files in sub projects not.
All reported paths are relative to the current working directory, however this directory changes during the build process. This change of directory is reported with statements like:
make[1]: Leaving directory '/media/psf/Home/GitHub/bash/bash-4.4/build/builtins'
make[1]: Entering directory '/media/psf/Home/GitHub/bash/bash-4.4/build/support'
In this kind of environment which is not that uncommon, it seems kind of impossible to get the problem matcher working properly. Depending on the area you are working on you have to edit the tasks file to get a correct link to the file.
To complicate things more the leaving statements pops back to the previous one, so if you parse the entering and leaving statements, it is not stateless. You have to keep track of a stack of directories.

data.title: I find it confusing that the keybindings.json can have mixed OEM and real characters
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: Insider 1.13
- OS Version: Windows

Testing> #27481 

In don't want to make the life for US users harder but the fact that we render OEM and real keys now in the keybindings.json is confusing for non US users. Do the following

- Swiss German layout
- create a keyboard short cut like by entering Ctrl+¨ into the widget
```
{
        "key": "ctrl+oem_3",
        "command": "workbench.action.toggleSidebarPosition"
}
```
- switch layout to US English
- create a keyboard shortcut using the widget entering Ctrl+`. You get
```
    {
        "key": "ctrl+`",
        "command": "workbench.action.toggleSidebarVisibility"
    }
```
- not that the command is different

Observe: At the end both bind to the same key however by looking at the file you don't see this. I would suggest that the key bindings editor (Sandeep) always tries to render the key to produce and the keybindings.json editor always renders OEM keys.

data.title: Unnecessary horizontal line in hover board hover
data.body:

![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1931590/26571566/cf6f6cf6-4516-11e7-8e6a-ba019e013c79.png)


The text reads for me "For your current keyboard layout press: Ctrl+§." so there should be no line between the first sentence and the key to press.

data.title: Option to add a file to gitignore directly from vscode
data.body: It would be cool if an option to select the file or folder and add it to gitignore on the fly from the file view pane

data.title: Bug -- Source Control: Git Side Bar -- Doesn't display correct staged filename
data.body:
# Issue

**Source Control: Git** side bar doesn't show the correct staged changes. Instead showing a file that doesn't exists (`DME.md` in the below picture instead of `README.md`). Clicking the file goes into a blank comparison view. Attempting to destage `README.md` with `git rm --cached` and restage with `git add` doesn't correct the issue.

git status | VS Code
--- | ---
![vscode-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5482320/26569616/b0030d74-44d9-11e7-90b6-40186e7ed05b.PNG) | ![vscode-bug--vscode](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5482320/26569618/b1be363e-44d9-11e7-86ed-312ccae75b7b.PNG)


---

# Steps to Reproduce:

**Note**: I was able to reproduce on both Windows 10 with Git Bash and a Fedora 25 instance

1. Clone [https://github.com/3ygun/tutorial-react-with-ts]()
2. On `master` revert the last commit with `git reset --soft HEAD~1`
3. See current staged files `git status`
4. Open the repo in VS Code `code --disable-extensions .`
5. Look at the **Staged Changes** in the Source Control: Git Side Bar
6. They shouldn't match the previous output of `git status` with `DME.md` instead of `README.md`

# Info

- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2 (19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de, 2017-05-10T13:20:36.315Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: **Issue reproducible with all extensions disabled** (Can provide the list if need be)

data.title: Test `editor.letterSpacing`
data.body:
Testing #18715 (came in as PR #22979)

- [x] Linux @Tyriar 
- [x] @roblourens 

Complexity: 2

There is a new setting called `editor.letterSpacing` where you can define (negative or positive number) the letter spacing for the editor font. Since fonts are complicated and character widths depend on the glyphs being used, we are not doing any smart validation that the value makes sense, so values such as -100 or +100 might be undesirable but I think they will be applied (I think the values are clamped at -20 -> 20.

data.title: Test that wordPattern is supported in language-configuration.json
data.body:
Testing #14221 (came in as PR #22478)

- [x] @jrieken 
- [x] @mjbvz 

Complexity: 1

You can now define a word pattern for a language also in the language configuration file. The field is called wordPattern and can be of type string or of type `{ pattern: string, flags: string }`. Please verify that you can define the word pattern for a language also from this external language configuration file (besides the existing way of calling setLanguageConfiguration).

data.title: Test some changed in behaviour of Home and End
data.body:
Testing #19644 (came in as PR #21338)

- [x] windows or linux @sandy081  
- [x] mac @isidorn 

Complexity: 2

Have some wrapped lines.

On Windows/Linux:
* end -> end of wrapped line
	* end x2 -> end of line
* home -> first character of wrapped line
	* home x2 -> first character of line
	* home x3 -> column 0

On Mac:
* cmd+right -> end of wrapped line
	* cmd+right x2 -> end of line
* cmd+left -> first character of wrapped line
	* cmd+right x2 -> first character of line
	* cmd+right x3 -> column 0
* ctrl+E -> end of line
* ctrl+A -> column 0

data.title: Symbolic names on Windows for non-US keyboard layouts
data.body:
Testing #26945 - this is a bug but I would like to get more than the usual quick verification to check that what we do now makes sense. At the end of testing, please feel free to add a verified label to the bug .

- [x] windows 1 @dbaeumer 
- [x] windows 2 @rebornix 

Complexity: 3

Under Windows, when using a keyboard layout which is not the US standard keyboard layout, in the Default Keybindings .json and in the define keybindings widget and in the `keybindings.json` we will now use symbolic names to talk about the key codes (such as OEM_2, etc.). The reason for this is that in the past we would print these symbolic key codes using the US standard produced character and this lead to a lot of confusion. The hope is that by using symbolic names, folks will understand that we are talking about key codes (which don't necessarily correlate with the produced characters). Anyways:
* please check that the symbolic names always come accompanied by an info box instructing towards the produced character (the label of the key)
* please check that you can use both the old way of referring to key codes and the new one: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/Keybindings#deciphering-keybindingsjson e.g. `OEM_1` === `;` when it comes to us parsing that file -- so if you defined keybindings before, they will work correctly.
* under the US standard keyboard layout (a majority of our users), we will still render these key codes using the US standard produced character to minimize the noise.
* please check that as you switch keyboard layouts, the fact that a key code is not mapped is reflected with a red indicator and a good message accompanying it.

data.title: Test editor.multicursorModifier
data.body:
Testing #27193 

* [x] OSX @bpasero
* [x] windows @chrisdias 
* [x] linux @isidorn  

Complexity: 2

There is a new setting `editor.multicursorModifier`. On Linux and Windows it can have the value `"ctrl"` or `"alt"`. On OSX it can have the value `"cmd"` or `"alt"`. Please check:
* the default is `"alt"` (just as before). So without any changes, out of the box, multiple cursors are added via `"alt"` + click. It is a known issue that under some Linux distributions, multiple cursors cannot be added via `"alt"` + click, which is used to move windows, this new option aims to also overcome this limitation.
* when using `alt` as the multicursor modifier: ctrl+click (cmd+click) is used for going to definition and opening links. ctrl+alt+click (cmd+alt+click) is used for going to definition and opening in a side editor and for opening a link in a side editor (you can craft a file:/// link to test this)
* when using `ctrl` or `cmd` as the multicursor modifier, the 3 features swap modifiers and going to definition / opening a link is alt+click. ctrl+alt+click (cmd+alt+click) will still be used for going to definition / opening a link to the side. The hover message on links correctly shows the modifier to be used to open a link.

data.title: Test Auto Accessibility Detection in the Editor
data.body:
Testing #14592 

- [x] mac with VoiceOver @isidorn 
- [x] windows with NVDA + [this plugin that increases the 30ms timeout]
 (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/26730#issuecomment-303439633) @michelkaporin 

Complexity 3

We are now leveraging Electron APIs to detect when Electron/Chromium enables accessibility support. This is done in the main process and communicated to the renderer processes. Please check that:
* when running VS Code, the Ln, Col indicator is shown in the status bar and the `<textarea>` the editor uses for input/output is empty. You can find the `<textarea>` in the dom and use `$0.value` in the console.
* when starting NVDA / VoiceOver with VS Code running, all VS Code windows detect this and the status bar shows "Screen Reader Detected". The editor now begins to output screen reader content to the `<textarea>`. You can check this by finding the `<textarea>` in the dom and using `$0.value`. Also, the screen reader should now read the text in the editor. The Ln, Col indicator is removed because it is triggering accessibility events that confuses NVDA.
* please also check other scenarios, such as first starting the screen reader and then launching VS Code, or reloading a window, or opening a new window, etc. In all cases, the fact that a screen reader is attached should be detected. This is important, because otherwise the editor does not output screen reader content to the `<textarea>` (which gives us a nice performance boost)

data.title: [Feature Request] Extend find/replace to support regex group replacement.
data.body: As per the below screen, I want to use the find/replace tool to replace a substring of a regex group match. I.e. given a file with the following string ` @param SmartCollection The updated SmartCollection. ` I want to use the following regex (\*.+)(SmartCollection) to replace all matches of SmartCollection with a new value. This is very useful when refactoring code that has been taken from another file / project.

data.title: Add history navigation for file include/exclude patterns in the search pane. Remember history between sessions.
data.body:
This implements https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/20547 for both the include and exclude patterns.

It also remembers the history for the search terms and the include/exclude patterns on shutdown and startup.

data.title: File extension association is not respected when file extension and language id share the same icon
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create an `icon A` theme and associate some icon to a `language id` (let's say Elm)
2. Associate another `icon B` to one of the extensions already associated  (in this case the only one `.elm`) by the extension supporting the `language id`. IMPORTANT: `icon B` must be already be in use by a `language id` association.
3. The expected behavior would be that the `.elm` files would show the `B icon` but instead `A icon` is being shown.

According to [vscode api docs](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensions/themes-snippets-colorizers#_file-association):

> A file extension match is preferred over a language match, but is weaker than a file name match.

Also, I remember talking to @aeschli about this in [vscode#10804](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/10804#issuecomment-243403933).

You can also view the original report in [vscode-icons#964](https://github.com/vscode-icons/vscode-icons/issues/964), specifically this [comment](https://github.com/vscode-icons/vscode-icons/issues/964#issuecomment-304836687)
